instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.KERNEL_TASK: What is KERNEL_TASK? KERNEL_TASK is a process that will take up all the CPU and cause the macbook to run very slow when there is a sensor issue. When you see KERNEL_TASK as a process taking up lots of CPU and the machine is working very slow or has loud fans, use a program like hwmonitor to check voltage, amperage, and temperature sensors and look for something that doesnâ€™t look right..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> High system load after minor liquid damage
threads.message: We're working on an early 2011 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Macbook Pro ( <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B ) that was brought in for light liquid damage.  There was no corrosion or any signs of actual liquid contact to the board.  We did replace the keyboard.  The device boots normally except it almost immediately starts to appear very sluggish.  When running TOP to see what resources are being used there's a system process called "<SIGNAL>KERNEL_TASK</SIGNAL>" that is chewing up 300% of all resources.  Looks like the machine is basically DOS'ing itself.  From a quick search online this can be caused by several things but most point to a bad sensor.  Can you point me in the right direction ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> High system load after minor liquid damage
threads.message: Bad sensor, figure out how to download and run ASD 144 and tell us what error it throws

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> High system load after minor liquid damage
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> High system load after minor liquid damage
threads.message: Ended up being a bad sensor.  Customer elected to replace laptop with newer model we were selling so while we didn't repair this one we did figure out the problem.
